Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Innovative Use of Internet Classifieds in Law Enforcement Investigations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the use of machine learning techniques on massive on-line information for identifying patterns useful in law enforcement practice and public policy. The quantity and complexity of public data make it impractical for manual browsing and tracking by investigative forces seeking to identify illegal activities. For example, there is a need to automate the process of detection of informative patterns in human trafficking, and especially sex trafficking. Ubiquity of the Internet provides the perpetrators, who take advantage of trafficking victims, with the ability to solicit services on advertisement web sites. This data is publicly available and contains information potentially useful to law enforcement investigators to understand crime patterns and to track the perpetrators. This team proposes to study the commercialization opportunity of a prototype analytic tool which they developed for the task. This technology may save time and increasing law enforcement productivity and effectiveness by providing new leads that would otherwise be missed.

This project provides a framework for demonstrating practical utility of machine learning research previously funded by NSF in a well-focused context of its societally important application. The proposed innovation has the potential to revolutionize the investigative process in the US at local, state, and federal levels. The vast amount of data online is currently underutilized. This project seeks to remedy this for general benefit of society. It would improve efficiency of law enforcement practice at all levels (local, state, federal), facilitate cross-agency collaboration, as well as enhance public policy studies. The proposed innovation will also have a broader application in leveraging public sources of data for detection and mapping of patterns of other illicit behaviors (e.g. sale of stolen and counterfeit goods) and non-illicit behaviors (e.g. economic activity, job seeking, lifestyle, and public health).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human trafficking, and especially sex trafficking, is one of the major unresolved problems facing our society.  An estimated 100,000 children are sold for sex in the US each year, and a vast majority of them are American. Each day, hundreds of thousands of Internet ads in the United States are used to market unlawful activities. 10-15 years ago, streets were the marketing venue for prostitution; the Internet has brought with it a preference by criminals for indoor prostitution and trafficking, making this crime nearly invisible, and harder for law enforcement to combat.  Sex slavery, the business of rape, was one of the worst fates we could imagine and we knew that even one child rescued from this fate would be worth it. 

Ubiquity of the Internet provides the perpetrators, who take advantage of trafficking victims, with the ability to solicit their services on advertisement web sites. This data is publicly available and contains information potentially useful to law enforcement investigators to understand crime patterns and to track the perpetrators. However, the quantity and complexity of this data make it impractical for manual browsing and tracking by the already overcommitted investigative force. There is a clear and present need to automate the process of detection of informative patterns in sex-related advertisements to make this readily available data usable, to support fighting this kind of crime, and to enable more effective rescue of its victims. We proposed to study the commercialization opportunity of a prototype analytic tool which we have developed for the task. 

The tool we have developed, Traffic Jam, leverages statistical data mining and machine learning to characterize and organize publicly available Internet escort advertisements for in-depth analysis by law enforcement in sex trafficking investigations. It is able to estimate probability of each ad to be indicative of a trafficking activity, and detect and track movement of suspected prostitution rings over time and space. It has a potential to include additional capabilities, relevant to its current or expanded use. This project aimed at thorough investigation of the specific needs of the anticipated users of this technology, estimation of the market opportunity, and identification of the most feasible ways of implementing and improving the tool, so it can be pragmatically used in investigation and prosecution of this heinous crime. It also provided a framework for demonstrating practical utility of a machine learning research previously funded by NSF in a well-focused context of its societally important application.

Our innovation has the potential to revolutionize the investigative process in the US at local, state, and federal levels. The vast amount of data online is currently underutilized. Our project sought to remedy this for the general benefit of society. It will improve efficiency of law enforcement practice at all levels (local, state, federal), facilitate cross-agency collaboration, as well as enhance public policy studies. The proposed innovation also has a broader application in leveraging public sources of data for detection and mapping of patterns of other illicit behaviors (e.g. sale of stolen and counterfeit goods) and non-illicit behaviors (e.g. economic activity, job seeking, lifestyle, public health, etc.). NSF I-Corps funding primarily supported development of a young analyst, and expose her to learning commercialization skills while interacting within the Program and with the potential end users of our technology. We disseminated publishable results of our investigation to data mining research and law enforcement practice and policy audiences.

The end result of our participation in the program was establishing of a successful startup company, Marinus Analytics LLC, designed to scale up, robustify, and deliver our Traffic Jam tool commercially to a large number of law enforcement users involved in combatting sex trafficking worldwide. The result is a powerful resource for law enforcement and prosecutors across the United States, Canada, and other countries where comparable Internet usage and sex trafficking trends exist. To date, this technology has been used to successfully identify over 300 trafficking victims and aid in the prosecution of the criminals who exploit them. We are proud to say that we hear stories from detectives often of how the technology has enabled them to rescue victims and identify crucial leads that they would otherwise not know about.  Our project was started with a mission to help those in need and we continue to improve the tool to solve the evolving challenges faced by law enforcement today, and broaden our impact to help the vulnerable in our communities.
